body.p: As we conclude our second year as co-editors of Remedial and Special Education (RASE), we extend our sincere thanks to the team of Associate Editors, editorial board members, guest reviewers, and Hammill Institute and Sage staff whose expertise and commitment continue to shape the journal in positive ways. We greatly appreciate the time and effort you have each invested in increasing the rigor, relevance, and reach of the journal. We also welcome new members of our consulting editor board who are beginning their 3-year term this January. Finally, we thank the numerous authors who turn to RASE as a compelling venue for sharing their scholarly work with the field.

We are pleased to report that the journal receives more than 120 articles per year, including research studies (about 70% of all articles), systematic literature reviews (about 15% of articles), and conceptual, policy, or position papers (about 15% of articles). Our acceptance ratio is now between 15% and 18%, making RASE among the more selective journals in the field. The average time from submission to final decision is approximately 60 days, meaning constructive feedback is provided to authors in a very timely fashion. Moreover, we now publish all accepted articles in advance online (http://rse.sagepub.com/content/early/recent) to ensure rapid dissemination to the field.

In the upcoming year, we will showcase a special issue entitled Issues and Advances in the Meta-Analysis of Single-Subject Research: A 25-Year Update. This special issue—edited by Daniel M. Maggin and Sandra M. Chafouleas—will provide a forum for leaders in the field to engage in renewed discussion and debate about the methods and merits of meta-analyses single-subject research. This special issue will be published nearly a quarter of a century after this debate was first launched in the pages of RASE (e.g., Salzberg, Strain, & Baer, 1987; Scruggs & Mastropieri, 1987; White, 1987). If you have an intriguing idea for a future special issue topic, we encourage you to contact us to discuss your idea. In the meantime, please visit http://rse.sagepub.com/content/early/recent to explore the many excellent and forthcoming articles already published in advance online publication. We close with an invitation to readers and contributors to provide feedback as we strive to further improve the rigor, relevance, and reach of RASE.
